awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Post-Quantum Cryptography in Resource-Constrained Devices
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is to deliver state of the art cryptography and cybersecurity solutions to Internet of Things (IoTs) and embedded device designers, enterprise hardware and software vendors, and government contractors against the attack of classical and quantum computers. It has been widely accepted that quantum computer attacks on today's security are expected to become a reality within the next decade. Some progress towards constructing quantum computers has been made, although no quantum computers with serious computing power have yet been built. Nevertheless, we believe it is prudent to plan ahead for future needs as it normally takes many years to change cryptosystem deployments due to network effects. This project plans to implement quantum-safe solutions which will require the integration of quantum-safe software and/or hardware cryptographic solutions on resource-constrained devices used in embedded systems.  

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project will design, develop, and implement cryptographic algorithms that are suitable for small and resource-constrained devices employing hard and complex mathematical assumptions known to be classical- and quantum-safe. All post-quantum cryptography candidates need to be evaluated in terms of performance while the target applications are resource-constrained devices. Long-term and lightweight security are two main parameters that need to be considered while deploying quantum-safe cryptographic algorithms in these devices. We plan to employ a special class of quantum-safe algorithms based on maps on elliptic curves to achieve the required performance and security. Cryptosystems based on these maps on the elliptic curves are known to provide the smallest possible key sizes and their security level is determined by a simple choice of a single parameter in comparison to the other quantum-safe candidates. The hardware designs are taken through VLSI design flow to realize the integrated circuits that are evaluated for energy/power, area/performance, and security. The project will generate new insights and results about how to be safe and secure in the quantum era. This project will also contribute to the ongoing standardization effort by the US government and other international organizations.

por.por_cntn:
As industries continue to develop quantum computers, security needs to develop to defend against their capabilities. Similarly, we are moving towards a fully connected world where every electronic device is seemingly connected to the internet, and thus creates a point of access of cyber-attacks. By developing post-quantum cryptographic solutions able to fit on even IoT devices we are working to keep all these devices secure. 

Specifically, we design and develop hardware and software solutions (Suite-Q HW and Suite-Q SW, resp.) for implementations of post-quantum cryptography on small and resource-constrained embedded devices employed in IoTs.

PQSecure is part of the SIKE Team which collaborated with several organizations from industry and academia to develop a unique solution for quantum-safe cryptography which has been submitted to NIST. It has recently been advanced to the second round of the NIST standardization process for post-quantum cryptography. SIKE offers the smallest key size in comparison to the other quantum-safe candidates which significantly reduces the communication overhead and fits in IoT devices. During Phase I, we were able to make significant improvements in timing for both hardware and software versions of our implementations and presented these results at several different industrial events. Moreover, we secured our intellectual property through developing and submitting patents.

We prototyped our Suite-Q SW and Suite-Q HW in real-world platforms such as ARM embedded processor (widely used in IoT) and FPGA platforms, respectively, and measured the performance and power/energy parameters.

For Suite-Q SW, we were able to develop and optimize software libraries for ARM implementation. We were able to reduce the timing results significantly in comparison to previous academic work, for the NIST recommended "Level 1" security on a Cortex-M4 device. Suite-Q HW results are even more promising. We were able to optimize hardware implementations for FPGA boards and reduced the time down to about 200 milliseconds for the same security level. We observed that for the applications where power/energy consumption is important, dedicated hardware crypto-processors are the way to go.

Our research and development outcome will help industry and government entities stay secure in the quantum age. Also, IoT manufacturing industries, through licensing, will get the benefit of our solutions on their devices to achieve quantum-safe security. Finally, our product will help with our national security by keeping our infrastructure secure against cyber-attacks.
